texts.en: Gulinor A. lives in the Vahdat region. She is 40 years old. She is married and has six children. Her husband is now working in Russia. She has secondary education and has been doing animal husbandry for ten years. She breeds mainly cattle for future resale. She is taking out the loan to buy cattle to increase their head count.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Sharipakhan's Group

texts.en:
Kyrgyzstan benefits greatly from having China as a neighbor. With a flourishing economy, China sees Kyrgyzstan as a bridge for export to Europe and the Middle East. An overwhelming majority of goods in Kyrgyzstan are imported from this growing neighbor.  China exports a vast variety of consumer goods, which lets many entrepreneurs in Kyrgyzstan run their businesses without having to cross the borders and leave the country.  

Sharipakhan U., 51, is the treasurer for this loan group.  She is a widow and a mother of a seventeen-year-old son.  She works in a government department, and runs a small retail business selling clothing on the weekends.  Her wholesaler delivers clothing and shoes from the town of Kara Suu, which is several hours away from her hometown.  

Being a year in business bore fruits, and Sharipakhan could afford to purchase new carpets and a TV set from her business earnings. She has many plans for the future, which include giving an education to her son, expanding her business, and maybe opening her own boutique. She is requesting a loan to purchase more wholesale clothing and shoes and also a head of cattle to resell. 

     --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and one cattle

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
What makes a good business entrepreneur? Personal characteristics? Relationship with environment? Or competitive advantage? All of these characteristics are related to our next ambitious borrower, but the main driving force is a unique idea and a strong faith in accomplishing it.

Gulnara M., 32, is the treasurer of this group. At this moment she is a housewife with two kids, but she has big business possibilities in the future. Gulnara’s husband is a truck driver. Several times a week he has to make hard long trips to remotest areas of the country. Transporting a large number of goods requires much patience and endurance. 

Their children are six and three years old and can now be taken to a daycare. So Gulnara plans to start a business selling consumer goods and groceries in a market in her hometown of Kerben. The wholesale goods will be brought by her husband during his trips. This will help her cut the  transportation costs significantly.   Her husband’s salary has already allowed the family to purchase several heads of cattle and send them to Gulnara’s parents for tending. 

The returns from the new business will be spent on constructing a house and setting up their own private shop. Gulnara would be very thankful to all lenders, since having a chance to sell goods in a local market is very important for her family’s well-being. 

  --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase products for resale

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with six children, five of whom had graduated while one is still attending school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has been operating a retail shop for the past four years, selling to her neighbouring community. In addition, she also operates a fresh water selling business and makes natural juices for sale to contribute to her income. Mwanamisi faces a major challenge in the seasonality of demands in her business. She hopes to sell as wholesaler in the future.

With the  20,000 Kshs, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and rice to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to run her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour and rice to resell

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
Current conditions in Kyrgyzstan drive the majority of residents to go into business. People are compelled to try in as many spheres as possible in order to make a living.  The rural areas are the most vulnerable to any changes in the nation. With no production and substantially low employment, rural areas are left without a labor force and became even more undeveloped, while the urban population grows.  

Nazira K., 35, is a treasurer of this group of borrowers. A resident of the small coal-mining town of Tashkomur in Southern Kyrgyzstan, she has been involved in livestock breeding for two years. She is a mother of four children and her husband is a coal miner. He sells coal to local consumers and to other regions of the city. 

Nazira says the biggest challenge for her is to pay enough attention to livestock breeding while raising four kids. Livestock needs careful treatment the whole day, starting from early in the morning until late in the evening. When the livestock is grown, Nazira sells it and buys new younger ones to raise.  This business always has enjoyed high demand because the Kyrgyz people’s main dish is meat. 

The business was Nazira’s husband’s initiative, thanks to which the family’s monthly revenue is 10000 soms. This loan is planned for the purchase of  9-10 livestock animals. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Mahmadrasul

texts.ru: Бобохонов Махмадрасул проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 46 лет. Женат. Имеет 5 детей. Образование-среднее. Более 8 лет занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян, минеральных удобрений и топлива. Он намерен посеять, и получит хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en: Mahmadrasul Bobohonov lives in the Vahdat region. He is 46 years old. He is married and has five children. He has secondary education and has been in agriculture for more than eight years. He grows mainly vegetables. He is taking out the loan to buy seeds, mineral fertilizer and fuel. He plans to sow and collect a good harvest for resale.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Jyparkul's Group

texts.en:
The flora of Kyrgyzstan is rich and varied due to the geographical location of the country. It has extraordinary masterpieces and accounts for more than 4,500 species of superior plants. Kyrgyzstan can be called a wonder of nature. Some very popular native flowers of this country are Tulip Grage, Tulips Kolpakovskiy, Tulip Bulbs Ilium, Gentiana Flowers and Perennials. 

Jyparkul K., 47, is the treasurer of this group. Flowers have been her passion for many years. She thinks she inherited this love from her mother, who was a professional florist. Every early spring Jyparkul paves the way for planting seeds of various types of tulips, roses and her favorite narcissus. April and May brings unbelievable beauty to her garden, which she expands every year. The whole neighborhood is amazed with Jyparkul’s flowers and asks her advice concerning all sowing processes. 

A year ago she talked her husband into starting to sell flowers in a local flower market. Soon the business prospered and attracted even foreign customers’ interest. Now it earns up to $170 a month and helps her provide her six children with daily necessities. In the future she plans to diversify her assortment and try to mix in some new types of flowers. She plans to spend the profits generated from this loan to purchase a small piece of land. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a wider assortment of flower seed

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
From Phnom Penh City of Cambodia, Chum N. is a 44 year-old. She is a housewife. She always does her housework as a daily duty, such as cooking, cleaning house, washing clothes, caring for her four kids, and other improvements in and around her house. 

She has a life partner in her husband who works in the construction field, earning a profit of approximately $5 each day for paying the whole family's expenses. The couple has four single children, two of whom are working in different jobs, and they often contribute their profits to Chum N. every month. 

She says that her two kids always need to hire a taxi to go their working place because they don’t have a vehicle, so she is taking out her loan to buy a motorcycle which will be used by her children to ride to their job location.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her kids to ride to their job location.

loans.name: Imomali

texts.ru: Бобохонов Имомали проживает в районе Вахдат. Ему 42 года. Он женат. Имеет 6 детей. Уже восемь лет как занимается растениеводством. Он в основном арендует земельный участок, где выращивает овощи для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений и семян.
texts.en: Imomali B. lives in the region of Vahdat. He is 42 years old. He is married and has six children. He has been in agriculture for eight years. He mainly rents out a plot of land where he grows vegetables for reselling. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.en:
Gulmira C. is 38-year-old mother of four children. She is a teacher of the English language in a school in Naryn town, and her husband is engaged in transportation services. Unfortunately, the salaries of teachers are very low and her husband's earnings don't cover their family's needs. 

In order to find an additional source of income, they decided in 2000 to engage in cattle breeding with an initial capital of 15,000 KGS. Gulmira and her husband work hard, and they have managed to develop their farm and expand their herd with a monthly income of about about $170.
  
Gulmira plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to further expand her herd for fattening and resale. In the future, she plans to reconstruct her house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with five children, two of whom have graduated from school, while three still attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a coconut selling business from home to her neighbors. In addition she also operates a food vending business which contributes to her other source of income. Saumu faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a permanent house in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to run her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of coconuts for resale.

loans.name: Trust Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
49-year-old N. Hamiati is now seven years down the tough and challenging stretch in her dairy business in Terere-Mukono. It is a business she began with the influence of her late husband with whom she had four kids, who luckily are still in school, thanks in part to finances from this business.

N. says that before her husband prevailed upon her to take a hand in this business undertaking, she was more inclined to a commercial farming business, which at length she has dispensed with. The determined and diligent N. says this business generates about $22 weekly. With this loan, she says she is going to purchase maize bran to resell. This is her side business. N. belongs to the Trust Development Group-Mukono.

loans.use: To purchase maize bran to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair the vehicle

loans.name: Rwashamaire Bakyara Twimukye- Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
R. Flavia is the leader of the Rwashamaire Bakyara Twimukye- Ntungamo Group. She is married with ten children. Flavia has a retail shop and a bar in Kagamba Junction that has been in existence for sixteen years. She is able to make weekly profits totaling about $65 and she is grateful that she has agriculture as a mother business. 

She opened up a retail shop and a bar because of the advice given to her by a friend. In addition, her hard work, friendliness and determination have done wonders for her. She hopes to expand her business further, construct a good house for herself and buy a car to help her in her businesses. Her loans have helped her in paying school fees for all of her children as well as expanding her business.

loans.use: Buying more general merchandise and beers for resale.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San H. has been in the farming business for many years in the province of Kompong Cham. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow rice crops, and she gets good results from her planting almost every year. Her husband assists her in the same business. They are blessed with six children, four of whom are single and two are married. Three of her children are working in various occupations. 

Soon San H. will plant her rice crop in her dry-season rice field, but she doesn’t have the capital to do it yet. To solve this problem, she would like to request a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizers and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizers and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Successful entrepreneurship cannot be achieved without certain skills and abilities. Just having financial capital and a desire to open up your own business is not enough. A newcomer in the business sphere needs to have an idea that he’s going to fulfill in practice, as well as the ability to survive  strong competition and stay in business by attracting more customers. 

Elmira Y., 27, has acquired good skills for a successful future in entrepreneurship, except the most necessary criteria – capital. Elmira works with technical personnel in two places of employment. She and her husband, who also acquired a job in the technical sphere, are young parents of three kids, the oldest of whom is six years old. Elmira’s husband has always told her that she’s got exceptional managerial skills. Elmira has always been good in managing the family finances and has used all the resources she had with minimum waste. 

Recently the family came up with an idea of starting to resell vegetables in a market in her home town of Tashkumyr. Vegetables and fruits are highly consumed by customers, and almost never lose demand. Elmira hopes that her experience in planning and organizing will help her in business. She expects high profits in the upcoming years and the successful repayment of the loan. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables to resell

loans.name: Furah

texts.en:
Furah is 30 years old and married to a teacher. They have three children. She lives in a family of six in their own home in Hioma, Uganda. 

She has owned a retail shop for four years now, which she started with a capital of 800,000 UGX that her husband gave her. She has the challenge of collecting bad debts. In the future she wants to have a wholesale shop. 

Furah wants a loan to buy sugar, soap and cooking oil for resale.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase synthetic hair and hair sprays for the salon.

loans.name: Essa

texts.en: Essa is currently in the business of selling locally brewed alcohol, like siko.  She is 44 years old, married with 3 children who all go to school.  Essa requesting a loan to stock more alcohol like siko and beer to sell.  She hopes to pay her children's school tuition with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more alcohol like siko and  beer to sell.

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
The young woman in the photograph is Im A., age 26, who lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming.  Im A. is a married woman who is devoted to her two young children who attend school and depend on her care. 

Im A. owns a piece of farmland that she inherited from her grandparents over six years ago.  Besides her farming business, Im A. raises a few pigs in the cage behind her house in order to earn extra profits to support her family.  Her husband is a local farmer.  This is the dry season and Im A. wishes to grow her crop in the dry season rice field, but she lacks money to make it possible.  In order to solve this problem, Im A. has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to purchase fertilizer and seed for planting.  With the rest of the funds, she will use it to buy a few sacks of pig feed for the pigs she is raising.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seed for planting.  The rest of funds will be used to buy a few sacks of pig feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing scrap metals.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 25-year-old married man with one child, living in a rented house in Hioma, Uganda. He has a vision of educating his child to the masters level.

He has a business of selling clothing in markets and has been doing it for four years. He started this business with savings from welding. He faces a challenge of bad debtors and wishes to have his own shop in the future. 

Moses needs the loan to buy more clothes for reselling,

loans.use: Buying more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Achiro

texts.en:
Achiro is currently in the business of selling foodstuff like beans, oil and charcoal. She is 33 years old, married to a prisoner, and has four children, three of whom go to school. 

Achiro took out a loan to stock more foodstuff to sell. In the future, Achiro hopes to pay for her children's schooling with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuff like beans, oil and charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Phork

texts.en:
The man shown in the picture is Mr. Phork N., 63, a fisherman. He usually needs to take eight hours a day to fish in the river next to his house. He catches around eight kilos of fish per day and sells them in bulk to his customers who are retail sellers in the market. 

He has no life partner because he was divorced from his wife years ago. He has eight children, four of whom are single and working in various jobs, while the other four are married and live independently. 

Mr. Phork N. will use his loan to purchase nets, traps, hooks, and other fishing implements so he can catch more fish.

loans.use: To purchase nets, traps, hooks and other fishing implements.

loans.name: Bulijjo Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
39-year-old N. Jemeo is affiliated with the Bulijjo Development Group-Mukono. Jemeo is happily married with three kids and has been making common cause with this group for the past six years. 

She operates her food selling business from the Bulijjo food market. Because she sells predominantly staple Ugandan foods like bananas, rice, maize flour, cassava, beans, etc., her client base cuts across the population and her niche in the market has been improving year in and year out. Jemeo says all credit for the establishment of this business goes to her mother. Prior to that her main source of livelihood was a poultry business. 

She says hard work, tenacity and an unwavering sense of determination have been her invaluable stock in trade. Weekly this business generates about $26. Jemeo says she is going to purchase more bananas and rice to resell with this loan.

loans.use: The purchase of more bananas and rice to resell

loans.name: Chak

texts.en:
Chak C. is a 58-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Cham province.  Chak C. was married but she divorced her husband years ago.  She earns her daily income by planting rice crops on her own farmland.  Growing crops is twice annual work with which she has had great success. 

She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both the rainy and dry seasons.  Recently, Chak C. is concerned that her only son will marry soon, but her personal saving is insufficient to help him hold his wedding.  To deal with this situation, Chak C. would like a loan from Kiva to add with her savings in order to assist her son to celebrate his wedding.

loans.use: To assist her son to celebrate his wedding.

loans.name: Enock Simiyu

texts.en:
Enock Simiyu K., a 34-year-old married father of four children, lives in Naitiri on the outskirts of Eldoret. A dairy farmer in business for three years, he earns a monthly income of 40,000 shillings. This will be Enock's first loan from KADET LTD with which he plans to buy cattle feed for the cows and sheep. He will use any extra income to purchase more animal feed.

In the future, Enock hopes to expand his business and educate his children to the highest level.

loans.use: To buy animal feed for the dairy cows

loans.name: Rahab Namunyak

texts.en:
Rahab Namunyak T., a 22-year-old married mother of four children, all in school, has been a hawker in Narok town for the last two years. She learned about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her first loan, with which she is planning to buy more stock, and hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her business.

An assiduous woman who is determined to achieve her goals, Rahab's dream is to educate her children to the university level and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of foodstuffs

loans.name: Devine Grace Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Jane  M., 42, who is a happily married mother of three, has been plying her stone quarry trade for the past 15 years in Kiganda and Kireka in Mukono. 

She says profits from her earlier business of charcoal sales were pivotal in helping her take root in this trade, which often calls for a lot of sacrifice in terms of time. Hard work is also needed if one is to obtain a solid footing in this trade. 

Jane has personified hard work through the years, and this trade generates 100,000 shillings weekly. 

With this Kiva loan, Jane says she is going to pay for more land to expand her stone quarry.

loans.use: The purchase of more land to expand her quarry

loans.name: Thou

texts.en:
Thou S. is a 30-year-old woman, married to Sem Soeurn, age 30. This  couple lives with their three children. 

To earn a living, Thou S. and her husband have been cultivating rice on their farmland since 1999. They can earn an average profit of $7.5 per day. 

In addition, Thou S.’s husband is also a construction worker. 

This rice harvesting season, Thou S. needs capital to purchase many sacks of rice to store. She will sell them later when the rice is commanding the highest price. She proposes to use the remainder of the loan to support his husband to buy construction equipment.

loans.use: To buy rice to store for later sale and to buy construction equipment

loans.name: Uulkan's Group

texts.en:
Uulkan E. K., 20, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Nookat, a small village near Osh, in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is divorced. 

In order to earn money, she breeds livestock. She began two years ago with an initial investment of 4,000 KGS. Her father helps her with that activity. She now earns 3,200 KGS per month. 

With money received from the loan she wants to increase the number of livestock. In the future she dreams of purchasing a house and improving her living conditions.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.ru: Чумаев Рахматулло проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Более 5 лет занимается растениеводством. Имеет участок земли, где выращивает овощи. Полученный урожай вывозит на рынок. Таким образом он зарабатывает на жизнь. Целью кредита является закуп семян и топлива для трактора.
texts.en: Rahmatullo J. lives in the Vahdat Region. 36 years of age. Married, with four children. He has been growing produce for over five years. He has a land plot where he grows vegetables. He sells his produce at the market. This is how he earns a living. The purpose of this loan is purchasing seeds and fuel for his tractor.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fuel

loans.name: Siyazama Group

texts.en:
Lindiwe Gloria T. is 54 years and married with six children between the ages of 10 and 28. Two of them attend school. 

She runs a tuck shop (a small convenience store) in Mtubatuba in the KwaZulu-Natal province of South Africa. 

She has been in the business for three years and she operates her business at her house. She also earns income from the government child support grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are clients who do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy more stock like cold drinks, sugar and other goods. She adds that the extra income from this loan will help her buy furniture for her home. In the future she would like to extend her shop.  

Lindiwe is pictured on the right raising her right hand.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her shop

loans.name: Nqubeko Group

texts.en:
Sibongile G. is 30 years old and single with three children between the ages of 9 months and 11 years. 

She runs a clothing business in Mtubatuba in the KwaZulu-Natal province of South Africa. She has been in this business for two years. She also earns income from the government child support grant. 

Sibongile says that the main challenges to her business are customers who do not pay on time. 

She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy new clothes to sell. She adds that the extra income from this loan will help her buy furniture for her family and renovate the house. In the future she would like to own a shop where she can sell her clothes.

Sibongile would like to thank WDB and Kiva for this opportunity.

In the photo she is on the right raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy new clothes for resale

loans.name: Gulnarahan's Group

texts.en:
Gulnarahan T. is the leader of this group.  She is a resident of Nookat, a small village near Osh (south of Kyrgyzstan).  She is 34 and married. She has two daughters and a son.  The daughters are both in school and the son is not yet.  

Gulnarahan works at a school and her husband earns money by providing car repair services.  He earns 4,000 KGSS per month.  With money received from the loan the family wants to purchase auto parts.  In the future Gulnarahan wants to provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase auto parts.

loans.name: Ntokozo Group

texts.en:
Veronica is 42 years old and a single mother with five children between the ages of 2 and 23 years old; she also cares for three relatives. She runs a clothing business and sells outside a mall and at a flea market in Empangeni, South Africa (KZN). In the photo above, she is standing on the left wearing a white shirt and a black and white skirt.

She's been selling clothes for two years. She also gets income from the government's child support grant. She says the main challenge for her business is that at times she does not have enough money to order clothes to sell. She also has difficulty selling when it's raining because she does not have a shelter yet.

She requested this loan through the Women's Development Businesses and KIVA to buy second-hand clothes in bulk and sell them. She says the extra income from this loan will help her build a house for her family and feed her children. In the future, she would like to own a building or room for her business with the help of WDB and Kiva. 

She adds that she is looking forward to working with WDB and Kiva and sees her business going forward with their help.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes in bulk and sell them

loans.name: Om

texts.en:
Om S., 31, is married to Rim, 33, and they are in the photo with their lovely kid. She has two small kids who live under her care. 

Her husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees behind his house. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in the commune. 

Om S. has a plot of farming land. She and her husband currently generate an income of approximately $5 per day. 

Om S. is looking for a loan to buy a few ladders to help her husband to climb the palm trees, and to buy a few small pigs to feed for selling.

loans.use: To buy a few ladders to help her husband climb the palm trees, and to buy a few small pigs to feed for selling.

loans.name: Rwabashenyi Fal Group- Ntungamo

texts.en:
K. Peace is the leader of Rwabashenyi FAL group in Ntungamo. She is 61 years old and married with grown-up children although she helps take care of grandchildren. 

She has an agriculture business where she grows matooke, beans, ground nuts and onions. She has been in business for at least 25 years, and she is able to make 80,000 as monthly profits. She grows her produce and sells to the market. 

She is very hard working and determined and she aims at modernizing her farming practices.

loans.use: Paying wages to her helpers at the farm.

loans.name: Burma's Group

texts.en:
Burma N., 36, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Nookat, a small village near Osh (south of Kyrgyzstan). She has two sons and a daughter. The daughter is in school and the other children are not yet. In order to earn money, her husband works in construction. He has a lot of experience in this activity; he built a house for the family by himself. The family needs money for purchasing building materials.  In the near future, Burma wants to build a fence near her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials

loans.name: John Kimisik

texts.en:
John Kimisik R. is fifty years old, married and a father of four children.  His family lives in Cheplaskei in the outskirts of Eldoret Town, and John operates a butcher shop where he buys cows, slaughers, and sell the meat.  He has been in this business for four years now and gets a monthly income of fifteen thousand shillings.

This will be John's first loans from KADET LTD, and he plans to use the entire loan to buy two cows, with the income he is going to get he wants to save and open another butcher in Eldoret town. 

In the future he wants to open a different kind of business and provide for his family.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim S. has been spending her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. 

She has two single children and they are studying in public school. In addition, Sim S. also has two daughters who earn their living by sewing clothes at the garment factory in Phnom Penh City. Recently, one of her daughters wishes to buy some products in order to sell, such as fast food, plastic products, and soft drinks. This is the reason why Sim S. has decided to request a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To assist her daughter to buy fast food, plastic products, and soft drinks for sales.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buying more bananas for resale.

loans.name: Khath

texts.en:
Khath S., 39, is from Kompong Tom and is married to Noun, 37. Khath S. has five children, two of whom are single. Two of them are employed in different occupations, and they always share their earnings with Khath S. for supporting the family. 

Khath S. earns his daily revenue by growing rice and climbing the palm trees in his village. Palm-tree-climbing jobs are very popular for people who live in the commune. His wife also helps him in the same business. Khath S. would like a loan in order to purchase a piece of land in good condition for a farming business. He will use this land for doing farming.

loans.use: purchasing a piece of land for farming

loans.name: Murere Ole

texts.en:
Murere Ole L. is 42 Years old, married and is a father of six children.  Murere is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last four years.

He learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his second loan which he is planning to spend and to prepare land for maize planting. Maize has been doing well in the area due to good climatic conditions.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.  Murere dream is to do large scale farming and be an exporter of maize overseas. He is a scrupulous man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to prepare land for maize planting.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar:
علي في عمر 35 سنة منزوج وله ولدان يحب عائلته يعمل في محل لبيع الخضار والفاكهة له في عمله 5 سنوات يرى
ان عمله يجب ان يتطور ويريد من خلال تطوير عمله الى تأمين العيش الكريم له ولعائلته واهتماماته هي تعليم اولاده بمستوى جيد
تاريخه جيد في العمل حيث ان زبائنه يقصدونه ويتميز بالصدق والدقة في العمل والمعالة الجيدة مع الزبائن
يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى اجراء تحسينات في البيك اب خاصته لكي يتمكن من نقل الخضار والبضائع بشكل افضل
texts.en: A., 35, is married with two sons. He has been working at a greengrocer's for 5 years. He wants to develop his work so that he can secure a decent living for himself as well as his family. He is also interested in providing his children with a quality education. He is known among his clients for his honesty, thoroughness, and good service.  A. wants to get a loan from A. Majmoua to improve his pickup performance so that he can better transport vegetables and fruits.

loans.use: To improve his pickup performance

loans.name: Jane Achieng

texts.en:
Jane Achieng M. is 34 years old, married and a mother of two school aged children. Jane is a business grocery woman and she does the business in the town, which she has been doing for the last eleven years.

She learned about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her third loan which she is plans to spend to buy more stock of food stuffs. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her business.

Jane dream is do educate her kids to higher level and expand her business. She is a persevering woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: to buy more stock of food stuff

loans.name: Tilebat's Group

texts.en:
Tilebat B. is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married. Her husband is a farmer. They earn money for their family by selling cattle. They have been doing it for 10 years. The family started to breed cattle with the initial investment of 40,000 Kyrgistani soms and now the monthly income is 12,000 soms. That profit made it possible for them to improve their living conditions and purchase a TV and DVD player. With money received from the loan Tilebat wants to purchase sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pay the rest of  his children's tuition installemts

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan O. is 57-year-old woman and mother who lives in the province of Kompong Tom. Chan O. has no a life partner because her husband died of senility many years ago. She has four children, and all of them are married. Three of her children are employed in different careers, and they always share their benefits with Chan O.. 

Chan O. owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. Chan O. has been cultivating rice since 1990, and she always gets good success with her planting following dry season and rainy season. 

Chan O. will be using her loan to add to her personal savings to buy a plot of her neighbor’s farmland near her house, which is a good location for farming. The loan will provide her with an additional new asset. 

Note: Chan O. and her grandson are in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Kabungo Women's Group - Ntungamo

texts.en:
Jolly B. is the leader of Kabungo women's group in Ntungamo. She is 49 years old and married with five children and all of them are still in school. She is able to educate them with the assistance of her husband.

For 12 years, Jolly has been in the business of selling produce, which includes beans, sorghum and maize, from Kabungo. She is able to make 100,000 UGX as weekly profits. She is also a farmer, growing other produce like bananas, which she also sells.

She needs a loan to be able to buy more beans, sorghum and maize. She is very hard working and her dream is to be able to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy beans, sorghum and maize for resale

loans.name: Kiv

texts.en:
Kiv R. is a 29-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom province. She and her husband work together in the farming business, growing rice. They have experience in this sector since 2007 and are earning a profit of about $4 per day. 

This couple has only one child, who is studying in local school. 

Kiv R.’s husband wants to buy a trailer to connect with his motorbike in order to pick up merchandise and use for the family. This is why she has decided to look for lenders on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a trailer for their motorbike

loans.name: Khayrullo

texts.ru: Бобохонов Хайрулло проживает в районе Вахдат. Ему 48 лет. Женат. Имеет 5 детей. Жена домохозяйка. Сам Хайрулло занимается растениеводством. Он арендует участок земли, где сеет пшеницу и выращивает овощи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Khayrullo B. lives in the Vahdat Region. He is 48 years old. Married, with five children. His wife is a homemaker. Khayrullo is a farmer. He leases a land plot where he grows wheat and vegetables. He has been in this line of work for 15 years. He is taking out a loan to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BEN de l’association SABALY est composé de 10 femmes mariées du village de Daellan, préfecture de SAN région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI. Les membres du groupe BEN vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles ont en moyenne 32 ans et au moins 3 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage, la  parenté et ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso il y'a 3 ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième cycle et évoluent dans les activités génératrices de revenus : tissus et divers articles il y'a environ 7 ans. 
SARA T. du groupe qui vend des tissus wax et bazin compte acheter avec son prêt, 10 pièces de wax et 9 complets de bazin.  Sa  clientèle est composée  d’hommes et de femmes.  Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako pour revendre à  SAN. Elle effectue une grande vente aux enseignants à crédit payable mensuellement.
 Elle prétend mensuellement à un bénéfice de 15.000FCFA. Les membres du groupe BEN compte utiliser leur bénéfice pour  rembourser la dette subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise pour pouvoir l’agrandir.
texts.en:
he Ben group of the Sabaly association is composed of 10 married women from the village of Daellan, San Prefecture, Ségou Region (The fourth administrative region of Mali). The members of the Ben Group live in large extended families; on the average, they are 32 years old, with at least three children. They know each other as neighbors or relatives and have joined the Soro Yiriwaso credit program three years ago. They are now on their fifth loan. Their line of business is selling fabrics and miscellaneous articles, something they have been doing for about seven years.

Sara T., one of the group members, sells traditional colorful fabrics, wax and “bazin” (damask-type cloth). She plans to use her loan to purchase 10 sets of wax fabrics and nine sets of bazin. Her customer base is composed of men and women. She stocks up in Bamako in order to resell in San. She sells a large portion of her wares to teachers, who pay her in monthly installments. She plans to have a monthly income of 15,000 West African Francs. The group members plan to use their income to repay the loan, provide for family needs and reinvest the rest into expanding their business.

loans.use: Purchasing traditional fabrics

loans.name: Geofrey

texts.en:
Geofrey A. is thirty-two years old, married to Rodah and the father of two children. He runs a retail shop in Soysambu on the outskirts of Kitale town. He has been in this business for five years now and he gets a monthly income of about $125.

This will be Geofrey's first loan from KADET LTD and he plans to use the entire loan to buy stock for his business, buying rice, sugar, cooking fat, etc. With the income he is going to get, he plans to save some money in the bank and to buy more items for his retail shop. 

In the future, Geofrey wants to expand his business and also become independent.

loans.use: To buy rice, cooking fat, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Shibel

texts.ar:
شبل في عمر 31 سنة يعمل في عمل فني النحت له في عمله 18 سنة يحب عمله ويتطور به دائما حيث انه شغفه يريد دائما التطور والتجدد له زبائن كثر من محيطه وهو مقصود في عمله له تاريخ جيد مع المجموعة يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى
شراء صخور لعمله يجد صعوبة في اثبات عمله في السوق حيث يجد منافسة عالية
texts.en: Shibel, 31, has been working in sculpture for 18 years. He has a passion for his work and always seeks to develop it. His many clients are from his circle of acquaintances. Shibel has many clients thanks to his good work.  He wants to get a loan from Al Majmoua to buy stones for his work. He finds it hard to make a name for himself due to fierce competition.

loans.use: To buy stones for his work

loans.name: Laidou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe LAIDOU  de l’association BENKADI I est composé de 7 femmes mariées de la sous préfecture de Yangasso, préfecture de SAN région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI. Les membres du groupe vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans et au moins 3 enfants. 
Les membres de ce groupe ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a 3 ans et sont à leur 5eme cycle. Elles évoluent dans les activités génératrices de revenus il y’ a environ 7 ans. 
MINATA T. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 40 cartons de poisson fumé et 300 kg de poisson frais au barrage de Talo et Yangasso pour revendre à  SAN et à Koutiala en gros à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle prétend mensuellement à un bénéfice de 12.500 FCFA tandis que les autres membres du groupe compte sur un bénéfice de 11.500 FCFA. 
Les membres du groupe compte utiliser leur bénéfice pour rembourser la dette, subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise pour pouvoir l’agrandir.
texts.en:
The Laidou group of the Benkadi association is composed of seven married women from the Sub-prefecture of Yangasso, Prefecture of San, Region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mal). The group members live in traditional extended familes. They are on the average 32 years of age with at least three children.

They have joined the Sor Yiriwaso credit program three years ago and are now on their 5th loan cycle. They have started earning an income about seven years ago. Minata Tanagara plans to use her loan to purchase 40 boxes of smoked fish and 300 kg of fresh fish at the dam of Talo and  Yangasso in order to resell it in San and Koutiala to male and female customers. She expects a monthly income of 12,500 West African francs, while other members plan an income of 11,500 francs. The group members plan to use their income to repay the loan, provide for family needs and reinvest the rest into expanding their business.

loans.use: Purchasing fish

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BADENYA de l’association Sabougnouma est composé de 4 femmes mariées du quartier Dabani de la préfecture de SAN région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI. Les membres du groupe BADENYA vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elle ont en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Les membres du groupe ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a 2 ans et sont à leur 3 eme cycle. Elles évoluent dans les activités génératrices de revenus il y’ a environ 20 ans.  
NATOGOMA T. qui est la vendeuse de condiments et de savons du groupe, compte acheter avec son prêt, 10 sacs de fakoye, 20 paniers de Sounbala, 10 paniers de potasse et 30 sacs d’oignon frais et 5 cartons de savons  à SAN et environnants  pour revendre à GAO en détail, en demi gros et en espèce.  
Elle espère mensuellement sur un bénéfice de 42.000FCFA tandis que les autres membres du groupe compte sur un bénéfice de 39.000FCFA, qui seront utilisés pour rembourser les prêts, subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise pour pouvoir l’agrandir.
texts.en:
The Badenya solidarity group of the Sabougnouma association is composed of four married women from the Dabani neighborhood, prefecture of San, in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members live in large traditional families. They average 45 years of age and five children each. They came together as neighbors and through ties of kinship. 

The group members joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago and are now on their 3rd loan cycle. They have been engaged in income-generating activities for about twenty years.

NATOGOMA T. is the group member who sells condiments and soap. She plans to use her loan to buy 10 bags of fakoye, 20 baskets of Sounbala, 10 baskets of potash, 30 bags of fresh onions and 5 boxes of soap in SAN and surrounding areas for resale in GAO at retail or wholesale, for cash.

She hopes to make a monthly profit of 42,000 FCFA while the other members of the group are hoping for a 39,000 FCFA monthly profit, which will be used to repay the loans, provide for the needs of their families, and to reinvest in their activities for expansion purposes.

loans.use: Purchase of miscellaneous items

loans.name: Jarkyn's Group

texts.en:
Jarkyn A. is the leader of this group. She is 30 and married to a builder. Together they are bringing up a 6-year-old daughter. She studies at school. 

In order to earn money, Jarkyn sews bags and sells them at the market. She started this activity five years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS. At the moment her monthly income is 15,000 KGS. 

With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase all the needed materials for sewing. In the future Jarkyn wants to expand her business and purchase a big house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make bags

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem S. is a 32-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. Sem S. has five children, all of whom are single and still live with her. 

She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow rice and vegetable crops. 

Her husband is currently a recycling seller. He buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires and plastic. 

Currently, he use his bicycle to pick up his products and it takes too long and he cannot use it in distant places. Because of this problem, Sem S. decided to request a loan to purchase a used motorcycle for supporting her husband’s business. 

Sem S. and her young child are in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle

loans.name: Jane  Kadenyi

texts.en:
Jane Kadenyi V. is fifty-one years old, married to Ephrahim V., and together they are blessed with eight wonderful children. Her husband works as a clerk while Jane does dairy farming. She has been in this business for eleven years and gets a monthly income of about $50.

This will be Jane's 4th loan from KADET LTD, and she has been repaying all other loans successfully. With this loan she wants to buy animal feed for her dairy cows.

With the income she is going to get, she will pay school fees for her children. In the future she wants to buy and own more cows so that she can expand her business and also educate her children further.

loans.use: To buy animal feed for her dairy cows

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BEN de l’association BENKADI II est composé de 6 femmes mariées de la sous préfecture de Yangasso préfecture de SAN région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI). Les membres du groupe BEN vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 7 enfants. 
Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Les membres de ce groupe ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et sont à leur 1er  cycle. Elles évoluent dans les activités génératrices de revenus il y’ a environ 6 ans et font l’achat vente de condiments et diverses marchandises. 
ASSATA D., la présidente du groupe, qui vend des condiments de tous genres à son domicile, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 12 paquets de cube maggi, 5 sacs de sel, 6 kg de poivre, ½ kg de laurier,  10 sacs d’oignon, 4 kg de l’ail, 2 sacs de choux, 1 carton de concentrée de tomate. Sa clientèle est généralement constituée de femmes. Elle s’approvisionne à Koutiala pour revendre à Yangasso à son domicile, en détail et en espèce. 
Elle prétend mensuellement à un bénéfice de 23.000FCFA tandis que les autres membres du groupe compte sur un bénéfice de 19.500 FCFA. 
Les membres du groupe BEN compte utiliser leur bénéfice pour   rembourser la dette subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise pour pouvoir l’agrandir.
texts.en:
The BEN group belonging to BENKADI II association is made up of six married women from the "sous-préfecture" of Yangasso, San Prefecture, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the BEN group live in big traditional families. On average, they are aged 39 and have 7 children. 

They know each other because of being neighbors or through kinship ties. The members of this group joined Soro Yiriwaso this year and are on their first loan. They have been involved in money-earning activities for about six years and they buy and sell condiments and various other merchandise. 

ASSATA D., the president of the group, who sells all sorts of condiments out of her home, intends to use her share of the loan to buy 12 boxes of Maggi cubes, 5 sacks of salt, 6 kg of pepper, 1/2 kg of bay leaves, 10 sacks of onions, 4 kg of garlic, 2 sacks of cabbages, and 1 box of tomato concentrate. Her clientele is generally made up of women. She buys her merchandise in Koutiala and sells it in Yangasso out of her home, retail and for cash. 

She says she makes a monthly profit of 23,000 F CFA where as the other members of the group have a profit of 19,500 F CFA. The members of the BEN group intend to use their profit to reimburse the loan, cover family expenses, and reinvest in their businesses so as to expand them.

loans.use: buying condiments for resale

loans.name: Jumabubu's Group

texts.en:
Jumabubu O., 62, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek. Unfortunately, she is a widow. She has eight children, and most of them are married and live separately with their families. In order to earn money, Jumabubu breeds livestock, and she also sells dairy products to make additional income. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase livestock for breeding. In the future, she wants to see her grandchildren get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line—People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstanat http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Yessica María

texts.es: La señorita Yessica tiene 18 años de edad, culminó sus estudios secundarios hace dos años, solicita Gs. 1.500.000 en 12 cuotas mensuales para la compra de materiales y pago de cursillo de la carrera policial, la misma cuenta con el apoyo económico de su padre, quien es constructor, y con el de su madre, quien es empleada doméstica. La señorita solicita el crédito a la Fundación Paraguaya  para dicha inversión, ya que manifiesta que gusta de dicha carrera y con la misma podrá ayudar a su familia a mejorar su calidad de vida y la de ella misma.
texts.en: Miss Yessica is 18 years old. She finished secondary education two years ago. She applies for a loan of 1,500,000 guaraníes, repayable in 12 installments, to buy course material and pay tuition fees for training in the police career. She can rely on the financial support of her father, a construction worker, and her mother, a housekeeper. Miss Yessica came to the microfinance institution Fundación Paraguaya and applied for this loan, because she has a keen interest in this career and at the same time she will be able to improve the quality of life of her family and herself.

loans.use: To buy course material and pay tuition fees to study at the Police Academy

loans.name: Kamel

texts.ar:
كامل في عمر 43 سنة يعمل في دهان السيارات + حدادتها له في عمله 25 سنة متزوج وله 5 اولاد يحب عائلته وعمله اولى اهتمامه
يسعى دائما وراء لقمة العيش ودعم عائلته وتحسين وضعها المادي والاجتماعي يريد دائما التطور والتجديد في العمل له تاريخ
جيد مع المجموعة حيث كان يلقى دعم كبير من عائلته وساهم في تحسين وضع عمله يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى شراء عدة للعمل + بضائع جديدة
texts.en: Kamel, 43, is married with 5 children. He has been working in the autobody repair and painting business for 25 years. He loves his family and cares a lot about his work. Kamel always works hard to earn his living, support his family and improve its sociA. and financiA. conditions. Kamel has a good credit history with A. Majmoua. He was fully supported by his family during his previous loan cycle. His previous loan helped him improve his business. Kamel always seeks to improve his working conditions. He wants to get a loan from A. Majmoua to buy tools for his work and new goods.

loans.use: To buy new tools for work and new goods

loans.name: Idalina

texts.es:
La Sra. Idalina es casada, tiene 5 hijos (2 varones y 3 mujeres), todos mayores de edad, ella se dedica a la confección desde el año 1978, anteriormente retiraba los trabajos de terceros pero gracias a los buenos trabajos que realiza decidió independizarse y así conseguir la mayor clientela.
Hoy día ella confecciona prendas de vestir como por ejemplo: camisas para damas y caballeros, pantalón de vestir y ropas de colegios.
En el negocio sus hijas la ayudan, cuenta que le va muy bien. Su objetivo es crecer como micro-empresaria y dejarles la experiencia a sus hijas para que puedan continuar dicha actividad. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de telas.
texts.en:
Mrs Idalina is married and the mother of five grown-up children (two sons and three daughters). She has been active in tailoring since 1978. In the beginning she worked for third parties, but thanks to her good work she decided to become an independent seamstress and thus get more customers.

Currently, she manufactures clothing such as shirts for men and women, trousers and school uniforms. Her daughters help her in her business and they are all doing very well. Idalina's goal is to grow as a small business owner and transmit her experience to her daughters, so that they can continue her activity. She applies for this loan to buy fabric.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Nurhan's Group

texts.en:
Nurhan E. is the treasurer of this group. She is 42 and married to the entrepreneur. She has two daughters and a son. All the children study at school. Nurhan earns money by selling air tickets. The family also breeds livestock to make additional money. They started to breed livestock five years ago with the initial investment of 15,000 soms. In this way, they earn an additional 2,000 soms per month. That money made it possible for them to make house repairs. With the money received from the loan, Nurhan wants to purchase two sheep, in order to resell them at a higher price after fattening them. In the future, she wants to expand her business and provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line—People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstanat http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Amer

texts.ar:
عامر في عمر 22 سنة غير متزوج يعمل في بيع ونقل الخضار والفاكهة له في عمله 6 سنوات دائم الطموح يريد دائما
زيادة اعماله وتوسيعها فهو دائما التجدد وحب العمل يتميز يالجد والصدق في المعاملة يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى صيانة البيك اب الذي يعمل من خلاله في نقل الخضار والفاكهة له زبائن من محيطه وجيرانه واصدقائه يقصدونه في المواسم
خاصةله خبرة واسعة في هذا المجال ويحلم بأن يصبح صاحب متجر كبير خاص به
texts.en: Amer is 22 years old. He is single and for six years, Amer has been selling and transporting vegetables and fruit. He is ambitious and seeks to expand his business. He constantly seeks development and loves his job. Amer is known for his seriousness and honesty. Through a loan from A. Majmoua, Amer would like to maintain his pick-up truck, which he uses to transport vegetables and fruit. His clients are his acquaintances, neighbors and friends. They seek his products over the different seasons. He aspires to own a large shop through which he can sell his products.

loans.use: Maintenance of his pick-up truck

loans.name: Pariken Ole

texts.en:
Pariken Ole P. is 38 years old, married, and is the father of five children. He is a farmer and works his own piece of land, which he has been doing for the last four years. He makes a good income.

He learned about KADET LTD from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his 2nd loan, which he is planning to spend to prepare his land for maize planting. Maize has been doing well in his area due to good climatic conditions. 

Pariken hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming. His dream is to do large scale farming and be an exporter of maize overseas.  He is a punctilious man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to prepare land for maize planting.

loans.name: Koryun

texts.en:
Koryun M. is engaged in cattle breeding. He raises cows and calves on his farm. He likes his occupation very much, and his wife helps him in farming. Thereby they keep their family and were able to develop their farm, which they have run since 2002. 

Along with farming, Koryun and his wife have their regular work. Koryun works at Lchashen village's administration, and his wife works as a teacher. 
  
Koryun seeks a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy four cows for his farm, which will help him increase his family’s future income. Koryun is 50 years old, and he lives in Lchashen village, Sevan area.

loans.use: To buy four cows for his farm

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.ar:
احمد في عمر 50 سنة متزوج وله 1 ولد يعمل في بيع الخضار والفاكهة له في عمله 30 سنة  يحب عمله ويسعى جاهدا لكي يتطور
ويزيد من مدخوله ومدخول عائلته يلقى الدعم الكامل من افراد عائلته حيث انهم يشجعونه على زيادة عمل جديد يتميز 
بالدقة في العمل والمثابرة على التطور يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء سيارة جديدة لكي تساعده في العمل
لنقل الخضار والفاكهة
texts.en: Ahmed is 50 years old. He is married with one child. For thirty years, Ahmed has been selling vegetables and fruit. He loves his job and seeks to increase his income and develop. Ahmed has his family’s support, and they encourage him to seek new business. He is known for his accuracy and perseverance. Through a loan from Al Majmoua, Ahmed would like to purchase a new car to help transport his vegetables and fruits.

loans.use: Purchase a car to transport vegetables and fruit

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar:
علي في عمر 37 سنة يعمل اكثر من 9 سنوات في النقل العام متزوج ولهاربع اولاد يحب عمله ويريد التجدد والتطور
وقد تعرض مؤخرا الى حادث وقد تضرر فان بشكل كبير ولكن بالمثابرة استطاع ان يكمل عمله ولكنه يريد قرض من المجموعة 
بهدف صيانة فان وإعادة عمله بشكل طبيعي له زبائن من السواح والناس التي تقصده للنقل يلقى دائما الدعم من العائلة
فهو محب لعمله وعائلته
texts.en: Ali is 37 years old. For nine years, he has been working in public transportation. Ali is married with four children. He loves his job and seeks development and innovation. Ali was recently involved in an accident that caused him great loss. However, his perseverance won out and he was able to resume work. He would like to obtain a loan from Al Majmoua to maintain his van and restore his business. Ali’s customers are mainly tourists and the general public seeking transportation. He has constant support from his family as he loves his job and his family.

loans.use: Minivan maintenance

loans.name: Leandre Martin

texts.fr:
Homme de 50ans, marié et père de 4 enfants dont l'âge varie ente 4 et 28 ans,. Trois de ses enfants sont scolarisé. Après avoir reçu sa première bourse universitaire, ayant une charge de 3 personnes il se lança dans le commerce d’alimentation en 1988 avec un capital de 300000 Frs et sa vente moyenne journalière était  de 25000 fr.Ayant déjà bénéficié d'un prêt a HOPE, il a rembourse sans difficultés et a des épargnes considérables.   
Avec ce second prêt il veut renforcer son stock en achetant 10 casiers de boissons non alcoolisée, 5 cartons de boîte de conserve, 2 carton de jus de fruits, 6 packs d’eau minérales, 1 carton de laits en poudre, 1 carton de boites de lait concentré sucré. 
Le premier  prêt lui à permis d’améliorer les conditions de son alimentations ou les désirs de ses clients sont satisfaits. 
Très aimable, tout le monde le connait, il fait preuve d'une bonne moralité et est entrain de se battre pour la prospérité de ses enfants les placer dans des bonnes écoles et construire une maison pour sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman is 50 years old, married, and the father of four children whose ages range between 4 and 28. Three of his children are or have been in school. After having attended the university on scholarship and responsible for three persons, he got into grocery sales in 1988 with an initial capital of 300,000 francs. His daily average sales amounted to 25,000 francs. Having received a loan from HOPE, he repaid it without difficulty and has considerable savings. 

With this second loan, he wants to expand his inventory by buying 10 crates of non-alcoholic drinks, 5 cases of canned goods, 2 cases of fruit juice, 6 packs of mineral water, 1 carton of tins of powdered milk,  and one carton of sweetened condensed milk. 	

The first loan allowed him to improve his little grocery shop where he is able to satisfy his customers' wishes. He is very pleasant and everyone knows him. He is an upstanding citizen and is working hard to see his children prosper, put them into good schools, and build a house for his family.

loans.use: 10 crates of non-alcoholic drinks, 5 cases of canned goods, 2 cases of fruit juice, 6 packs of mineral water, 1 carton of fins of powdered milk,  and one carton of sweetened condensed milk

loans.name: Fabrice

texts.fr:
Homme de 33ans célibataire et père d’un enfant âgée de 5ans. Ayant un niveau universitaire et n’ayant pu décrocher du travail, et ayant 3 personnes en charge, il se lança dans le commerce de vente de tissus en 2003 avec un capital de 200000frs. Sa recette journalière est de 25000 à 70000frs.Ayant fini le premier cycle avec succès, avec ce second prêt il compte acheter des différentes qualités de tissus de cérémonie, de soie, de super 100 et d’autres tissus de première marque dont la demande est forte.  
Il use de beaucoup de stratégies pour épargner, attirer sa clientèle, et présenter les meilleurs prix a ses potentiels clients et ceux en dépit de la hausse des marchandises sur le marché.
 
Le prêt précédent lui a permis d’avoir un second étalage dans le marché. Les conditions de vie de sa famille s’améliorent de jours en jours.
texts.en:
This man is 33 years old, single, and has a 5-year-old child. Unable to find work despite having a university degree and with three people in his care, he started selling fabrics in 2003 with a capital of 200,000 frs. His daily revenue varies from 25,000 to 70,000 frs. He completed a first loan cycle successfully and plans to use this second loan to buy various grades of ceremonial fabrics, silk, super 100 and other top brand fabrics in high demand. 

He has a strategic approach to saving money, attracting clients, and offering the best prices to his customers despite the higher cost of the merchandise on the market.

The previous loan had allowed him to have a second booth at the market. The living conditions of his family are improving steadily.

loans.use: To buy bolts of ceremonial fabrics, satin, denim, velvet, wild silk and poplin

loans.name: San Miguel Group

texts.es:
El Comité San Miguel, se conformó en fecha 05 de marzo del 2010, gracias a la actual Directora de Finanzas, la Sra. Celia F., quien ya formó parte de otro grupo, al desintegrarse dicho grupo ella invitó a sus amigas y vecinas para la conformación del grupo, logrando juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto en el 4º ciclo.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de  868.750 Gs., lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de verduras y frutas, chipas (comida típica del país), etc.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo.
texts.en:
San Miguel Group was formed on March 5, 2010, thanks to its current Finance Director, Mrs Celia F., who was already a member of another group. When that group broke up, she invited her friends and neighbors to create a new group, getting together 16 women who are very comfortable working together. They are now in their fourth loan cycle.

The average loan per member amounts to 868,750 guaraníes and will be used to finance different activities, such as selling vegetables and fruits, chipas (a typical dish in Paraguay; it is a bread product made from corn flour and starch and baked in an oven heated by firewood), etc.

The group members participate actively in their weekly meetings and are grateful to the microfinance institution Fundación Paraguaya. They are all busy with income generating activities and help each other to reach their common goals.

loans.use: To buy bananas, apples, oranges, pineapples, peppers, onions, tomatoes, melons, grapefruits, etc.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.ar:
خالد في عمر 37 سنة متزوج وله 5 اولاد يعمل في محل لبيع خردوات السيارات له في عمله 15 سنة يحب عمله ويريد تطويره
يسعى وراء لقمة العيش وتحسين وضع اولاده وتطوير نفسه في المجتمع يتميز بالتوسع في العمل حيث انك تلقى لديه جميع قطع السيارات
يريد طلب قرض من المجموعة بهدف توسيع المحل وتركيب استندات + سقف للمحل بهدف زيادة الخردوات في المحل
texts.en: Khaled, 37, is married with 5 children. He works at a shop that sells auto accessories. He likes his business, where he has been working for 15 years. He works hard to earn his living, in order to improve his own status as well as his children's in society. He works in various types of auto accessories. Khaled wants to get a loan from A.
