Charmilyn is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Charmilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen C. is a married woman who lives in Carmen, Cebu. Her husband, Policarpio, who is 45 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 5 and 11 years old.

Carmen earns her living by operating two business ventures: ready-to-wear clothes sales and a rice business. 

Carmen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carmen has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, with which she intends to purchase ready-to-wear products to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business. 

Carmen is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
Sorm S. H., 28, is a married woman who sells fish as well as vegetables in and around the province Kompong Tom province. 

Her husband is a motor taxi driver in and around his village. Before he begins his taxi service, Sorm S. H.’s husband always assists her in buying fish and vegetables from their regular supplier at a reasonable price. After that, they use his motorbike to take their products to the busy market for resale.

Recently, she has wished to pick up her items in a bigger amount than at present. So Sorm S. H. has decided to seek a loan in order to purchase a trailer to connect to the motorbike so that she can use it to pick up more fish and vegetables. 

The family usually generates a profit of about $4.30 per day. They have two children living under their care.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer for the motorbike to haul more products

loans.name: Tseyenpil

texts.en:
Tseyenpil A., 63, is married and lives with his wife and a son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a house made from a shipping container on a small plot of land that they own, surrounded by a fence. This container was previously used to transport goods by truck. 

His older son studies abroad and the younger son goes to college. 

Tseyenpil operates a jewelry-making business. He began his business as an antique dealer in 1992 and has been operating his business for 19 years so far. Now he is a well known dealer and individuals come to his home to sell their items. 

He purchases every kind of antique item and uses them to make jewelry or sells them at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. He has a pretty big collection of antiques that he is going to sell in the future. 

Tseyenpil is a very experienced man with a lot of initiative who is popular as an antique dealer. He says,"If you tell my nickname Halhyn Ih Lanjuu, almost every antique collector would recognize me."  

He plans to open his own antique shop in the future and therefore he needs to increase his profit. He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase more antiques for his business as people sell their antiques at a lower price during Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian traditional New Year.

loans.use: To purchase more antiques

loans.name: Basran's Group

texts.en:
Basran is very supportive in nature. She always ready to help her family in their time of need. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the improvement of her son’s shoe-selling business. Her son’s shop is located in the market where he sells ladies' and children's shoes to his customers. With the loan, he will buy shoes of different varieties and will display them at his shop. He has 10 years of experience in his business and Basran is hopeful that a loan investment will bring more profits to him. 

Basran herself is a seamstress and sews clothes for her community clients. She is very good at her work and receives regular orders every month. She also carries out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. 

Her husband’s name is A. A. and he is also involved in shoe sales. Basran has given birth to four sons and two daughters. Three of her sons operate a shoe sales business while the others are getting their education. Shoe sales has become their family business since most of the members of her family are involved in the same profession. 

Basran is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. She comes from Arifwala which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its dairy industry. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Basran.

loans.use: To buy shoes for shoe-selling business

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Marry A. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 41 years old. Marry is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marry owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Marry has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marry joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Marry is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Marry from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure
